weblit-Navigation.intro: How do you get around the web? Browsers are the software we use the web – they can quickly direct us exactly where we want to go, or can take us on a winding path to serendipitously discover new interests. Improving web navigation by customizing your browser with add-ons is a wonderful way to take control of your web experience.

discover.title: Firefox Browser
discover.description: Find out about the different parts of a Firefox browser with these tips and tricks

discover.title: Resize your browser
discover.description: Learn the size of your browser window on this handy “What's My Browser Size” tool

discover.title: Firefox is Free
discover.description: Remix this “Firefox is Free” webpage by modifying it for your own chosen browser

discover.title: “The Filter Bubble”
discover.description: Watch Eli Pariser's TED Talk “The Filter Bubble” to learn more about online filtering

discover.title: Evolution of the Web
discover.description: An interactive timeline of the web

make.title: Firefox Add-Ons
make.description: Trick out your Firefox Browser with Add-ons https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/?application=firefox

make.title: Navigation Superhero
make.description: Hack your browser (Getting updated by Atul/Jess) http://toolness.github.io/hackasaurus-parable/navigator-badge/

kits.title: Ways of the Web
kits.description: Lead learners through the Ways of the Web with this hands-on teaching kit
kits.author: Mozteach

kits.title: Become a mentor
kits.description: Help others become web savvy, level up their critical thinking online, and get the most from the web

kits.title: Webmaker Training
kits.description: Get free training from Mozilla and learn how to teach credibility, privacy, and other essential skills for web literacy

more.title: Share a resource
more.description: Teach navigation skills by adding links, activities or curricula you've had success with in your own work [link]

weblit-WebMechanics.intro: What happens when you browse the web? Clicking on a link or entering a URL in your browser initiates a series of behind the scenes operations that define your experiences on the web. Recognizing the relationships between the moving parts of the web like IP addresses and URLs makes the overall browsing experience more rewarding, and helps you make smart choices about the content you consume and share online.

discover.title: URL Demystifier.
discover.description: Where in the world is the computer that hosts your website located?
links: Enter any address in the URL Demystifier to find out. http://url-demystifier.toolness.org/

discover.title: Find out who owns the Internet
discover.description: Read about the ownership structures of the world's largest public resource

discover.title: What is my IP address?
discover.description: This tool will show you what IP address you're using right now.

discover.title: Host Name Converter
discover.description: This tool will show you how the domain name of the site you're visiting is converted to an IP address by your web server.

discover.title: Not a Series of Tubes
discover.description: Despite popular belief, the Internet is neither a series of tubes nor a web browser. This video explains how the Internet is a collection of files connected to a domain name that link to each other.

make.title: Mash up the web with Popcorn Maker
make.description: See how embedding resources from sites like Wikipedia or Flickr depends on web mechanics https://popcorn.webmaker.org/editor/61795/remix.

make.title: Use a browser, hack a webpage
make.description: Wouldn't it be cool if you could “hack” websites like Google and Facebook? Now you can – and you'll learn about the back-end of web mechanics while doing it. https://tbx.makes.org/thimble/your-first-hack

kits.title: Speed dating for web mechanics
kits.description: Make learning about the elements of the web fun for students.
kits.author: Julia Vallera

kits.title: The Markup Mixer
kits.description: A Post-It note activity that helps learners build a basic understanding of markup.
kits.author: @malesser + @thomashpark

weblit-Search.intro: Can the web be harnessed? With millions of new web pages being added to the Internet every month, the web can feel chaotic – even overwhelming. Using effective search techniques can make the difference between a frustrating web experience and an empowered one.

discover.title: Search engine optimized versus search engine friendly
discover.description: What's the difference? This handy article shines a light on the topic

discover.title: Search box histories
discover.description: Learn about the human history of the search box via Google Search Education:

discover.title: Creative Common's own image search
discover.description: Find an openly-licensed image using different content providers on this Creative Commons search hub

discover.title: How does Google Search actually work?
discover.description: Learn how Google Search works in this video from the Google Search team

discover.title: The Internet Archive's Way Back machine
discover.description: View what your favorite web sites looked like in the past at the Internet Archive's WayBack Machine

discover.title: What is the world searching today?
discover.description: See what the world is searching for using Google Trends

discover.title: I don't want my searches to be tracked....
discover.description: Search without allowing your searches to be tracked using Do Not Track by Firefox

make.title: How to customize Twitter hashtags
make.description: Make hashtags on Twitter using this WikiHow tutorial http://www.wikihow.com/Use-Hashtags-With-Twitter

make.title: Make your own Google search engine
make.description: A tutorial on how to add a search box to your homepage to help people find what they need on your website https://www.google.com/cse/

make.title: Change your browser's default search bar
make.description: Step-by-step instructions on how to change the search bar in various web browsers http://www.searchenginejournal.com/change-your-default-search-engine-in-firefox-google-chrome-ie/

kits.title: Hold a SEO battle with kids
kits.description: Facilitate this activity to help learners get their websites at the top of Google Search
kits.author: meredith

weblit-Credibility.intro: Can we believe everything we see on the web? The internet contains a confounding mix of facts, opinions, advertising, hidden agendas and pranks. Sharpening your BS detector helps you identify credible content on the web, and reminds you to approach certain web sites with a healthy dose of skepticism.

discover.title: Crap Detection 101
discover.description: Howard Rheingold offers some fantastic ideas on how to separate accurate information from inaccurate information, misinformation and disinformation.
links: Check out <a href='http://rheingold.com/2013/crap-detection-mini-course'> Howard's Crap Detection mini-course

discover.title: The “CRAP Test”
links: This quick and easy evaluation process helps you analyze the legitimacy of a web pages by considering its Currency, Reliability, Authority and Point of View.

discover.title: Internet Detective
links: Decide whether a site is legitimate by learning to look for clues and evidence.

discover.title: Journalist's Toolbox
links: Detect urban legends, hoaxes and scams with this comprehensive toolbox used by journalists for myth-busting, fact-checking and more.

make.title: Punk a friend
make.description: Remix your buddy's social media profile, news article, or their favorite web site and give them a funny surprise with XRay Goggles

make.title: NewsJack remix
make.description: Remix a news web page by changing the ads, altering headlines, and exploring the visual and linguistic cues that signal credibility

kits.title: Create your evil twin
kits.description: Teach people to Use HTML and CSS, to create a profile page for their Evil Twin.
kits.author: mozteach

kits.title: Create your evil twin
kits.description: Teach people to Use HTML and CSS, to create a profile page for their Evil Twin.
kits.author: mozteach

more.title: Common Sense Media teaching plan
more.description: A set of resources made by Common Sense Media to guide students through the process of evaluating good sources of information on the web

more.title: Digital Disruption Toolkit
more.description: Tools and lesson plans designed to improve your student’s ability to critically evaluate information they encounter online

ctas.title: Become a mentor
ctas.description: Help others become web savvy, level up their critical thinking online, and get the most from the web

ctas.title: Get free training from Mozilla
ctas.description: Learn how to teach credibility, privacy, and other essential skills for web literacy

ctas.title: Share a resource for teaching credibility skills
ctas.description: Add links, activities or curricula you've had success with in your own work

weblit-Security.intro: Is it possible to stay safe online? The web works by connecting every computer and device in the world – this offers us astounding opportunities, but also exposes us to significant risk. The web can be safe with the right skills, tools and software, giving us the power to remain secure.

discover.title: Install these 10 Firefox add-ons to secure your web browser
What is Heartbleed?
links: Learn about one of the web's most serious vulnerabilities, and how to combat it < a href='http://heartbleed.com/'>http://heartbleed.com/

discover.title: Add-ons that block ads
discover.description: Learn more about Adblock Plus, an add-on that prevents sites from employing cookies that track your activity online, and it also blocks irritating website ads.

discover.title: University of Texas's guide to preventing identity theft
discover.description: Identity theft is serious business. Here is a primer to understand the key signs you may have been a victim of it.

discover.title: The security mirage by Bruce Schneier
discover.description: The feeling of security and the reality of security don't always match, says computer-security expert Bruce Schneier. In this talk he explains why we spend billions to address certain kinds of risks while avoiding others.

make.title: Create a how-to video for the Lightbeam project
make.description: Learn about the Mozilla Lightbeam project, which tracks those who are watching you online https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/lightbeam/ and then add your own flavor to the issue by remixing this Popcorn video and enhancing it with your own sound and images https://laura.makes.org/popcorn/1oj6

make.title: A graphic novel about mobile security
make.description: Modify this Thimble page created by a Webmaker community member to add your own take on mobile security in graphic novel format https://ryancalmon.makes.org/thimble/mobile-security-11

make.title: Create a strong Internet password
make.description: This article and the companion video by the Mozilla Support team will show you how to create secure, easy-to-remember passwords https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/create-secure-passwords-keep-your-identity-safe

kits.title: Hold an X-Ray Goggles Gallery Walk
kits.description: Help youth to express their thoughts on privacy by hacking websites that house their personal information
kits.author: the Our Privacy Matters! team

kits.title: Share privacy and security concepts with learners
kits.description: This teaching kit outlines a set of hands-on activities for helping participants learn basic privacy practices quickly
kits.author: Laura Hilliger, Dumitru Gherman, Emma Irwin, Ben Moskowitz, Atul Varma, Alina Hua, Stacy Martin, Matthew Willse, and Shane Caraveo

kits.title: Remix for cybersafety
kits.description: Show your learners how to explore security through remix with X-Ray Goggles
kits.author: Laura Hilliger, Dumitru Gherman and Emma Irwin

weblit-Composing.intro: What makes creating for the web different? Hyperlinks, multimedia, up-to-date content – these features make the web powerfully interconnected and entirely different from media of the past. When you write and build specifically for the web, recognizing that your audience is as much a part of the creative process as you are will allow you to tell stories and build experiences in ways that television, books and other media cannot.

discover.title: A brief history of storytelling
links: Explore the connections between early cave paintings, video games and today's web.

discover.title: What do screens want?
links: An essay by designer Frank Chimero examines what makes creating for the web unique.

discover.title: Explore some introductory HTML
links: This Code Academy tutorial is great for learning the very basics of HTML code.

discover.title: Get familiar with HTML and CSS
discover.description: Coding cheat sheets that help you with the basics.

discover.title: The Machine is Us/ing Us
links: Watch a viral video about what makes hypermedia (the web) different

make.title: Make an “About Me” page
make.description: Tell the web the story of you.

make.title: Animated JavaScript poem with the National Writing Project
make.description: Make a poem beautiful with dynamic text effects.

make.title: Bring a book cover to life
make.description: Become the author of your own international best-seller.

make.title: Movie poster template
make.description: Broadcast your brilliant project with a handy template that makes it into a feature poster.

make.title: Create your own glitch music video
make.description: Use a tutorial by glitch-artist Max Capacity to learn the process of creating a music video using your own content and creative methods.

kits.title: Teach an introduction to HTML, CSS & JavaScript
kits.description: Help learners become web literate through hands-on learning with the building blocks of the web.
kits.author: Webmaker community member Tech Kim

kits.title: Facilitate storytelling with the New York Times
kits.description: This teaching kit by the National Writing Project facilitates a set of exercises that work with code, storytelling and remix in journalism
kits.author: The National Writing Project

kits.description: A Post-It note activity by Webmaker community member Thomas Park that helps learners build a basic understanding of markup
kits.author: Thomas Park

more.title: Explain HTML tags with Digital Corps
more.description: A fun exercise for learners to replicate the structure of a basic HTML document.

weblit-Remix.intro: Many of our greatest creative accomplishments are made as a reaction to someone else. Nowhere is this more evident than on the web. Remixing the ideas of others by adding your own spin can let you turn something old into something new, talk back to media, or stand on the shoulders of giants to make your own statement on the web.

discover.title: Listen to a remix. These mashups are songs made from bits of other songs.
links: The Grey Album, DJ Dangermouse's remix of JayZ and The Beatles.
Girl Talk creating a mashup on his couch by remixing Elvis Costello.
Pop Danthology 2013: a mashup of 68 different songs.

discover.title: Watch DJ Kutiman's “Thru You” remix.
links: A mashup created by remixing hundreds of uploaded You Tube clips

discover.title: Learn about sampling and hip-hop.
links: “Raiding The 20th Century” by DJ Food is an in-depth exploration into remix

discover.title: Watch a documentary about remix culture
discover.description: Like Rip: A Remix Manifesto or Everything is a Remix.

make.title: Remix a web page.
make.description: Use X-Ray Goggles https://goggles.webmaker.org/ to remix any web page – your Facebook profile, the Google start page, NBA.com, or anything.

make.title: Bring together web links to create your own animated music video.
make.description: With help from glitch-artist Max Capacity: https://popcorn.webmaker.org/editor/60433/remix

make.title: Remix a TV commercial.
make.description: See what happens when you use the Gendered Advertising Remixer http://www.genderremixer.com/ to overlay toy commercials for girls over toy commercials for boys and vice versa.

make.title: Build audio video mashups from text.
make.description: Using HyperAudio http://hyperaud.io/

make.title: Mashup photos with animated gifs
make.description: On your iPhone using Pop https://gopop.co/

kits.description: Use this teaching kit to work with Popcorn Maker in three easy steps
kits.author: MozTeach

kits.title: Teaching remix with the X-Ray Goggles.
kits.description: Help people learn basic web basics by remixing web pages

kits.description: Remix popular internet memes by putting your own spin on them
kits.author: Christina

more.title: Remix your museum's art collection.
more.description: Hold a Cultural Heritage Remix Jam with the help of Tate Britain https://keyboardkat.makes.org/thimble/cultural-remixjam By Kat Braybrooke, Mozilla and Luca Damiani, TATE.

more.title: Bust media stereotypes.
more.description: Use remix to challenge and talk back to media stereotypes https://techkim.makes.org/thimble/busting-media-stereotypes By TechKim.

weblit-DesignAccessibility.intro: Should using the web be enjoyable for everyone?  As more people across the globe come online with phones and tablets, ensuring that the web is viewable across multiple devices has become an increasingly urgent challenge. Understanding CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) and the principles of good design help make interacting with webpages a pleasure.

discover.title: Know your font
discover.description: Try this quiz by Ironic Sans to test your knowledge

discover.title: Design for Programmers
discover.description: A series of 50 interactive challenges to learn how to implement design online

discover.title: Designer's News
discover.description: Browse through a Hacker's News-style feed tailored to designers

discover.title: Your website on different devices
discover.description: See what your site looks like in different formats with this Am I Responsive tool

discover.title: Web accessibility primer
links: Understand how people with disabilities experience the web http://webaim.org/intro/

discover.title: What Screens Want
discover.description: Find out what it means to design with screens in mind in this article by Frank Chimero

discover.title: An Interactive history of design
links: Learn about some of the field's key events http://designhistorytimeline.com/

discover.title: Hexidecimal color picker
links: Learn how the web reads colors http://color.hailpixel.com/

discover.title: Meet the design community
links: Get inspired by what people are making on Dribble https://dribbble.com/shots and Nice http://www.niice.co/

discover.title: CSS Diner
links: Learn advanced CSS tricks with this fun coding game http://flukeout.github.io/

discover.title: Resize that!
links: Play this responsive design jigsaw puzzle http://resize.thatsh.it/

discover.title: Test your webpage's accessibility
links: with WAVE, a tool that helps you evaluate the effectiveness of its elements for those with disabilities http://wave.webaim.org/

make.title: Design your own e-book cover
make.description: Learn CSS by remixing this starter template https://thimble.webmaker.org/project/14661/remix

make.title: CSS: Coding with Style
make.description: Learn how to implement design in code at Code Academy http://www.codecademy.com/courses/css-coding-with-style/0/1

make.title: Try building your own webpage with Skeleton,
make.description: a minimalist boilerplate that facilitates responsive, mobile-friendly designs http://www.getskeleton.com/, or with Bootstrap, a clean interface for front-end developers http://getbootstrap.com/2.3.2/.

make.title: Download the Firefox Accessibility extension
make.description: to emulate web-browsing experiences for a variety of special needs http://firefox.cita.uiuc.edu/index.php

kits.author: codekat

kits.title: A beginner's guide to game makery
kits.description: Facilitate learning around basic game design principles with this interactive and fun teaching kit
kits.author: Mozteach

weblit-CodingScripting.intro: How does the web respond to you? Interactivity has become essential to our web experience. How does that work? Small programs known as scripts run in the background of our web browsers automating hundreds of tasks and allowing our web experiences to be seamlessly responsive.  Understanding the role of scripting languages like JavaScript helps us maximize the interactive potential of the web, making our overall online experiences more useful and satisfying.

discover.title: Learn JavaScript
links: Explore the Mozilla Developer Network's JavaScript resource for beginner to advanced programmers.

discover.title: Why Programming Matters
links: Watch this Hour of Code video where programmers explain how scripting changed their life.

discover.title: Computer programming with Khan Academy
links: Check out this Khan Academy course in computer science.

discover.title: JavaScript for Cats
links: A fun introduction for new programmers.

discover.title: Learn Javascript while gaming
links: Play Code Combat, a fun game that teaches programming.

make.title: Hello, Processing!
make.description: Make web graphics with this fun, step by step guide to the Processing language.

make.title: Dance the Robot Boogie
make.description: Learn how to mix design with JavaScript.

make.title: Coding Maps with Leaflet.js
make.description: Make an interactive web mapping application using the Leaflet.js JavaScript library.

make.title: Code your own Python script
make.description: Learn about the with this interactive tutorial.

kits.title: Creating for the modern web
kits.description: Teach contemporary web design using web APIs and web fonts
kits.author: Stefan Bohacek

kits.title: Minecraft: A flavor of Java
kits.description: Share programming skills with kids using Minecraft
kits.author: EPIK - Dorine and Luke

kits.title: Code Thief
kits.description: This card game teaches JavaScript offline
kits.author: Chad Sansing

weblit-Infrastructure.intro: What's the difference between apps, the web and the Internet? There's a bewildering array of words used to describe the global network we use to communicate and share data. Understanding the basic underlying technology that makes up the Internet, and how it differs from the web and services like email, helps us grasp what happens to the data we share and guides us towards making safer, more intelligent choices online.

discover.title: What's the difference between the Web and the Internet?
links: This article on Wikipedia explains it all http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#Function

discover.title: What is the Internet, Really?
discover.description: Andrew Blum's TED talk about the underwater cables, secret  switches and other physical bits that make up the net.

discover.title: The Internet Stack
discover.description: Understand how the foundational technologies of the web work

discover.title: Printing out the Internet, page by page
links: A crowdsourced art project to print out the entire Internet, in honor of deceased open free-information activist Aaron Schwartz http://printingtheinternet.tumblr.com/

More about this project in the Washington Post http://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/print-this-web-page-mail-it-to-mexico-citys-labor-gallery-make-art/2013/07/26/534e2582-f320-11e2-ae43-b31dc363c3bf_story.html

discover.title: The Cleverest ways to use Dropbox
links: Dropbox makes full use of the architectures of the web and the Internet. Learn how to use it to its full potential http://lifehacker.com/5527055/the-cleverest-ways-to-use-dropbox-that-youre-not-using

discover.title: The Story of Send
discover.description: Take a journey through Google’s data centers by following an email along its path.

discover.title: How the Internet works in 5 minutes
discover.description: The Internet is not a fuzzy cloud. This video by Aaron Titus explains how the Internet is a wire, actually buried in the ground.

make.title: Draw your understanding of the Internet
make.description: Take part in this global art project by submitting a drawing that demonstrates your understand of the Internet http://www.canyoudrawtheinternet.com/

make.title: Create a page for the Internet Defense League
make.description: Do you believe in a free and open Internet? Remix this statement by the IDL to share your views https://chongkim.makes.org/thimble/LTExMjgwMDU2MzI=/internet-defense-league

make.title: Why do you believe in the open web?
make.description: Is the web about collaboration and communication for you? Or, is it about wires, tubes and machines? Why does it all matter? Tell the world with this Thimble page https://thimble.webmaker.org/project/17857/remix

kits.title: Speed dating for web mechanics
kits.description: Make learning about the elements of the web fun for students.
kits.author: Julia Vallera

weblit-Sharing.intro: Great ideas should be shared. For a concept to grow from a seedling into a tree, it needs to spread beyond one or two people and into the community. Co-creating on the web with diverse groups of stakeholders and open tools can yield unexpected solutions to vexing problems and mutually beneficial relationships.

discover.title: Ten leading platforms for creating online communities
discover.description: Browse this ZDNet list of tools that help communities organize people on the web and accomplish work in a highly collaborative manner

discover.title: Radical tools to empower communities in the museum sector
discover.description: As museums go digital, more activities are created and produced through community collaborations. This blog post discusses the approaches of the Santa Cruz Museum of Art and History.

discover.title: How can I share large files online for free?
discover.description: Lifehacker review of some of the best services to share easily and quickly with friends and colleagues http://lifehacker.com/what-s-the-best-way-to-share-large-files-with-friends-1486810038
links: And a similar list by PC Advisor http://www.pcadvisor.co.uk/how-to/storage/3509067/how-send-large-files-free/

discover.title: Asynchronous and synchronous classroom discussion methods
discover.description: Thoughtful examination of e-learning management systems for different kinds of learner needs by the Chronicle of Higher Education

discover.title: A short written history of collaborative methods
discover.description: Wiki page by the University of British Columbia that outlines the tools, sources and theories of group communication from the 1940s to the present day

make.title: What kind of web do you want?
make.description: Remix this Thimble greeting card in honor of the web's 25th birthday to share what the open web means to you https://mozilla.makes.org/thimble/the-web-we-want

make.title: A corkboard for idea-sharing

make.title: Publishing web apps with social media attached

kits.description: The tools outlined in this teaching kit help girls see themselves as technology producers with unique passions and skills that can transfer between platforms, makes and careers.
kits.author: the MozFest 2013 Girls in Technology Scrum Group

weblit-Collaborating.intro: There's only so much one person can do alone.  Fortunately, the web allows us to connect with others across distances, languages and cultures. Honing our online collaboration skills lets us do more than just send better emails – it helps us build things on the web faster, better and smarter.

discover.title: The 7 habits of effective online discussion participants
discover.description: Ways to make your experience of online forums more productive

discover.title: Github, Academia and Collaborative Writing
discover.description: Git's decentralized nature makes it an excellent tool for coordinating collaborative editing.

discover.title: How the Web Changed Everything
discover.description: Watch this talk by Cory Doctorow, one of BoingBoing's founding editors, on how the web lets us use collaboration to be “super human”

discover.title: Effective Crowdsourcing
discover.description: Check out these Mashable articles on different kinds of crowdsourcing

discover.title: The birth of Wikipedia
discover.description: Watch this TED talk by Wikipedia's founder Jimmy Wales.

make.description: This introductory tutorial shows you how to get started https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Introduction

make.title: Crowdsource your research experiment
make.description: Pybossa http://pybossa.com/ and Crowdcrafting http://crowdcrafting.org/ are two great tools made for projects that need community input and guidance

kits.author: Karen Smith

kits.title: Paper Prototyping Teaching Kits
kits.description: Collaborate with other educators to design Open Educational Resources together
kits.author: codekat

weblit-Community.intro: Why should the web be open?  In recent years, corporations have tried to control the web through proprietary software and private, walled-off sections of the Internet. Learning to collaborate online as part of a global community of contributors and creators is an empowering way to ensure that the web remains a shared resource for everyone.

discover.title: Mozilla Community guidelines
discover.description: Participation Guidelines for participation in the Mozilla Community

discover.title: GitHub Community guidelines
discover.description: Github provides code management for groups and communities. Here are its various participation guidelines

discover.title: The Hive Learning Network
discover.description: Hive creates opportunities that enable learning through hands-on making and exploration with peers and mentors. Learn about the path towards creating and sustaining this kind of network here

discover.title: Digital Is
discover.description: An open community of educators sharing, publishing and remixing each others work

discover.title: Source
discover.description: Source is a OpenNews project designed to amplify the impact of journalism code and the community of developers, designers, journalists, and editors

discover.title: Mozilla Science Lab

more.title: Peers working in the open
more.description: The syllabus from the Teach the Web MOOC in 2013 looking at community participation http://hivenyc.org/teachtheweb/week-6-peers-working-in-the-open/

weblit-OpenPractices.intro: Who can make the web? The web is universally accessible – its technologies are rooted in open standards that can be studied, reused and improved by anyone. Licenses define what's possible with the code and content we find online, and understanding how they work allows you to participate in the web's evolution.

discover.title: What is openly licensed content?
discover.description: This wiki page by Creative Commons explains the basics.

discover.title: What are OERs?
discover.description: This page by UNESCO explains what OERs (Open Educational Resources) are, and how they might manifest in our societies
links: And here's another useful description by the London School of Economics http://clt.lse.ac.uk/digital-and-information-literacy/OERs.php
Want to know even more? Here is a comprehensive guide by JISC http://www.jisc.ac.uk/publications/programmerelated/2013/Openeducationalresources.aspx

discover.title: The evolution of open knowledge – a crowdsourced community timeline
links: A history of openness from 1425 to the present day, based on events contributed by communities http://openbook.okfn.org/timeline/ And here's the project this timeline was built for, The Open Book: http://openbook.okfn.org/

discover.title: Yochai Benkler TED talk: Open-source economics
links: In this 17 minute speech, law professor Yochai Benkler explains how open and collaborative projects like Wikipedia and Linux represent the next stage of human organization http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NgYE75gkzkM

discover.title: The 9 most important events in open source history
links: What are the key moments in time that made open source software such an immense success story? http://royal.pingdom.com/2010/01/15/the-9-most-important-events-in-open-source-history/

discover.title: An overview of some of the most popular Open Source Licenses
links: Written by the Open Source Initiative http://opensource.org/licenses

discover.title: Learn about P2PU's School of Open
What's happening in open source today?
links: This online publication focuses on how open source is applied to different areas including business, education, government, health, law and other disciplines http://opensource.com/

make.title: Contribute to an open source project on Github
make.description: This useful guide will help you get started quickly https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/

make.title: License your web content using Creative Commons
make.description: This page leads you through the process of choosing the right license for your work. http://creativecommons.org/choose/

make.title: Create your own open source project
make.description: Creating an open-source project isn’t just about making your code freely available to others. This step by step guide in Smashing Magazine explains how to make it happen: http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2013/01/03/starting-an-open-source-project/

make.title: Report on an event and release its content for free
make.description: Remix this Thimble page to share the details of an event or meetup and share its content with a creative commons license of your choice https://thimble.webmaker.org/project/43402/remix

kits.title: Join a Webmaker Training session
kits.description: Wondering how to apply open practices to Webmaker? Get involved in the next Webmaker Training and learn how to teach vital web literacy skills in your own community:
kits.author: Community

kits.title: And here's a quick “Get Started” page
kits.description: that you can remix for your own needs
kits.author: @laura

kits.title: What's the right license for the job?
kits.description: Choosing the right CC license for a work can be a deliberative and thought-provoking process, but it doesn't have to be. This activity by P2PU helps learners understand how to pick the right license for the job.
kits.author: P2PU

kits.title: Design Challenge: Cultural Licenses
kits.description: Facilitate this activity by Mozilla's Kat Braybrooke and the Tate Britain's Luca Damiani to lead a group through the process of determining an open cultural license and then discussing how it works with different kinds of content
kits.author: Kat Braybrooke, Mozilla

kits.title: Understanding Hacking with Hive India
kits.description: This kit by Webmaker community member Tanay Pant shares a variety of articles that help mentors spread awareness about the “open” sides of hacker culture
kits.author: Tanay Pant
